column7: Middle English: Old French descrier 'publish, proclaim', perhaps confused with obsolete descry 'describe'

noun [mass noun]
The loss or giving up of something as a penalty for wrongdoing:
magistrates ordered the ____ of his computer
adj bad-tempered or unreasonable, esp because one cannot do or have what one wants: a ___ and jealous wife + ___ children. ___ly ___ce: He tore up the letters in a fit of ___ce.
adj 1 not safe; dangerous: He was unable to get down from his ___ position on the rocks. 2 depending on chance; uncertain: She makes a rather ___ living as a novelist.

t__ noun
A long, angry speech of criticism or accusation:
a ____ of abuse

noun [mass noun]
1The medieval knightly system with its religious, moral, and social code:
the age of ____
• The combination of qualities expected of an ideal knight, namely courage, honour, courtesy, justice, and a readiness to help the weak:
tales of ____ and knightly deeds
• Courteous behaviour, especially that of a man towards women:
he still retained a sense of ____ towards women

adjective
Reluctant to draw attention to oneself; shy:
everything you need to know but have been too ____ to ask
suddenly ____, she could think of nothing to say
don’t be ____ about telling folk how you feel
to commit a crime
e__ adj thin and weak: he looks very ____ after his long illness.
a__ v to change sth slightly in order to correct an error; to make an improvement in sth: [Vn] ____ a document/proposal/law + The Official Secrets Act has been ___d to prevent further leaks.
p_7_ n ~(of sth)(fml) a sign or warning of a future event, often an unpleasant one; an omen: The event proved to be a ____ of the disaster that was to come.

noun [in singular]
A state of near-unconsciousness or insensibility:
a drunken ___
v to press or rub sb/sth gently with the mouth or nose: [Vn]; [Vpr, Vp] The dog ___d (up) against me on the sofa.

v 1(esp passive)(of sth undesirable) to spread over and occupy a place in great numbers: [Vn] a warehouse ____ by rats 2 to continue beyond or exceed the time allowed or the expected cost: [Vpr] The lecture ___d by ten minutes. [Vn]

w__ verb [no object]
Make a slight involuntary grimace or shrinking movement of the body out of pain or distress:
he ___d at the disgust in her voice

verb [with object]
1Enjoy greatly:
he was ___ing his moment of glory
• Anticipate with pleasure:

adj ~(for sth/sb) (to do sth) (fml) giving or indicating a good chance of success; favorable: It was not a ____ time to start a new business.

q__ noun
A soft boggy area of land that gives way underfoot:
torrential rain turned the building site into a ____
• An awkward, complex, or hazardous situation:
a legal ____

n +___v to make a gesture to sb showing what one wants them to do, where they should go, etc: [Vpr] He ___d to the waiter. [Vn.to inf, Vpr. to inf] He ___d (to) me to sit down. [Vpr. to inf] The old lady ___d for him to get out. [Vnpr] ___ sb to a chair [also Vnp].
m__ v (usu passive) to cause sb to be very ashamed or embarrassed: [Vn] He was/felt ___d that he hadn't been invited.

c__ n [CGp] 1(a) a military force composed of two or more divisions: the 6th Army _cap_. (b) one of the technical branches of an army: the Royal Army Medical _cap_. 2 a group of people involved in a particular activity: the Diplomatic _cap_ (i.e. all the people representing foreign states in a particular country).

r__ verb [no object]
1(Of a comment or fact) cause continuing annoyance or resentment:
the casual manner of his dismissal still ___s
• [with object] Annoy or irritate (someone):

2archaic (Of a wound or sore) continue to be painful; fester:
the wound is but skinned over and ___s still at the bottom
column7: Middle English: from Old French rancler, from rancle, draoncle 'festering sore', from an alteration of medieval Latin dracunculus, diminutive of draco 'serpent'

she ___d him in his ribs
[no object] :
he ___d at the air with his finger
• Roughly or quickly thrust (a sharp or pointed object) someone or something:

i__ v 1 ~sb (with sth)(esp passive) to give or send sb so many things that they have difficulty dealing with them all; to overwhelm sb 2 to cover an area with a very large amount of water; to flood a place.
a hard, usu white, stone, often with dark veins, which can be highly polished. 大理石

verb [with object]
Take the place of (a person or thing previously in authority or use); supplant:

column7: Late 15th century (in the sense 'postpone, defer'): from Old French superseder, from Latin supersedere 'be superior to', from super- 'above' + sedere 'sit'. The current sense dates from the mid 17th century

column2: r__ v 1 ~sb(from sth) to wake sb: I was ___d (from my sleep) by the doorbell ringing.
a__ adj [usu attrib](esp Brit) (a) existing or occurring before birth (b) for pregnant women: ____ clinics

b__ n 1 [sing] (a) a person's way of standing, walking, etc; deportment (a): a man of upright, military ____. (b) behaviour: her dignified ____ throughout the trial. 2 [U] ~on sth    the way in which sth is related or relevant to sth. 3 [C] (techn) a direction that is measured from a fixed point. 4 a device that allows part of a machine to turn smoothly
n a person who was born in, or is a citizen of, the same country as another: The Australians claimed their ___s worked harder than the British. + Steffi Graf's German ____, Anke Huber.

n a large basket with a lid, esp one used to carry food, wine, etc: a picnic ____.
v (often passive) to prevent sb's free movement or activity; to restrict or hinder sb/sth: [Vn] Our progress was ___d by the bad weather.

n 1 [U] any plant disease: potato ____. 2 [C] ~(on sb/sth) any force that indirectly harms or destroys sth: The bad weather cast/put a ____ on our holiday. 3 [U] an ugly or neglected state, esp of a city: the ____ of inner-city slums.
o__ 1 to rule or treat sb in a continually cruel or harsh way 2 to make sb feel anxious, unconfortable or unhappy

v 1 to provoke sb's interest or curiosity: [Vn] What you say ___s me --- tell me more. [Vn. to inf] I was thoroughly ___d to hear what she had to say. 2 ~(with sb) to make and carry out secret plans, often with other people, with the aim of causing sb harm, doing sth illegal, etc; to plot2 v +___ n ___ing adj ___ingly adv
n [U] an extreme lack of energy or enthusiasm for doing anything; a lazy state: She suffers from bouts of ___ and depression. +government ___ towards the film industry.

j__ v 1 to push roughly against sb, usu in a crowd
2 ~ (for sth) to compete with other people in a forceful manner in order to gain sth
IDM (infml) to make sb lose their confidence and enthusiasum; to discourage sb: Failing the exam has ___d all ___ ___ ___ ___ him.
column4: knock the stuffing out of sth

column2: n v 1 to pull sth/sb suddenly and quickly in the specified direction: [Vnpr] He ___d the fishing-rod out of the water. 2 to move or make sth/sb move with a short sudden action or a series of such actions: [Vn] Try not to ___ the camera.

Ⅱ v 1 (a) to move one's head or upper body down quickly so as to avoid being seen or hit: [Vpr] I saw the gun and ___d under the table. 2 to go or push sb under water for a short time. 3 ~ (out of) sth (infml) to avoid a duty, responsibility etc.
intended to last or be in force only for a short time, temporary
